technical_features.source_sentence: The maximum adsorption capacity obtained from Langmuir fitting was equal to 146.28 mg P/g.
Our 1/n value obtained for phosphate adsorption by BC-5 was equal to 0.41.

The highest fitting accuracy was obtained when we fitted our adsorption data using the Sips model, which implies that phosphate adsorption on the BC-5 surface was a combination of mono- and multilayer adsorption.
The Ca content in the BC-5 sample was 7.72%.
The highest adsorption efficiency (equal to 93.33%) was achieved at pH = 11.
The equilibrium adsorption capacity calculated from the pseudo-second-order kinetic equation was 87.55 mg P/g.
After BC-5 adsorbed phosphate, the P content increased from 0.21 to 3.84%.

qualitative_insights.main_objective: Prepare Ca-enriched biochar from sheep manure and oyster shells for efficient phosphate removal from wastewater while utilizing agricultural waste.
key_methodology_summary: Pyrolysis of sheep manure at 500°C under N₂ atmosphere
Chemical modification with HCl-treated oyster shell solution
Adsorption experiments with varying phosphate concentrations/pH
Characterization via SEM-EDS, FTIR, XRD, and ICP-OES
primary_findings_conclusions: Maximum adsorption capacity of 146.3 mg P/g (Langmuir model)
94% phosphate removal efficiency at optimal conditions
Primary mechanism: Ca²⁺-PO₄³⁻ complexation forming hydroxyapatite
Adsorption capacity increases with pH (89.5-93.3 mg P/g at pH >7)
limitations_discussed_by_authors: Reduced surface area (4.74 m²/g) and pore volume after Ca modification
Interference from NO₃⁻ and SO₄²⁻ anions in solution
future_work_suggested_by_authors: Optimization of biochar:shell ratio and pyrolysis conditions
Exploration of other calcium-rich waste materials
novelty_significance_claim: First use of oyster shell waste for biochar Ca-modification
Dual waste valorization strategy for sustainable phosphate removal
Comparable performance to synthetic Ca-modified biochars (96.56-197 mg P/g)
key_tables_figures_present: Langmuir isotherm and pseudo-second-order kinetic models (Figs 4-5)
Comparative adsorption capacity table vs other Ca-biochars (Table 4)
